title: A strategy too good to refuse? From 'consigliere' to Suncorp's Don
text:
The question is whether Johnston, officially crowned chief executive last month, can help hurdle the company’s obstacles with a refreshed strategy.

In his favour, the man who sleeps a maximum of five hours a night is regarded as a smart, seasoned operator. Once he was dubbed Suncorp’s “consigliere”, a term used for advisers to mafia Dons.

But questions also arise about his past operational experience and responsibility in the flawed execution of a Suncorp strategy.

Mergers and politics

Johnston’s ties to Suncorp stretch to the company’s fusing of two lenders and a state-owned insurer in 1996. He was then Queensland premier Rob Borbidge’s senior adviser and helped push through merger legislation.

“It was tough,” Johnston told The Australian Financial Review. “You [had] votes of no confidence in the creation of the enterprise, given the speculation of job losses and branch closures.

“You had to balance out all the competing interests.”

The company swelled in ensuing years, acquiring GIO and Promina, whose brands included AAMI. Then it faced global financial crisis terror as collapsing funding lines threatened financial institutions. Suncorp pulled through and by 2016, then CEO Michael Cameron unveiled a new strategy: “Marketplace”.

Advertisement

Marketplace envisioned Suncorp as central to a digital finance zone – like an Amazon of finance-associated products. A customer, for instance, using Suncorp’s app to look for a house might search for a loan, insurance and pest inspection services. Links to outside companies were offered.

Cameron’s advocacy came with him warning Suncorp faced a potential extinction event akin to Kodak – the film stock and camera maker that missed the digital revolution – if it competed only on price for commoditised products.

The problem was some investors saw Marketplace as a reanimation of Suncorp’s flawed cross-selling strategy of the 2000s. Insiders were confused, perceiving teams had different interpretations of the strategy.

Meanwhile, cost-cutting was further aggravating employees. One staffer sued over his dismissal, with federal court documents obtained by the Financial Review alleging he was overloaded with work, and his own manager told him to “suck it up” and everyone was dealing with “resource shortages”.

But then Cameron resigned in May, with accounts stating he earned a $6.5 million pay packet that financial year, including $1.67 million in termination benefits. Also leaving in August was “customer marketplace” chief Pip Marlow, who earned $1.98 million in 2019.

The taboo word

Marketplace is now disappearing from terminology – no one used the word in annual general meeting speeches last month.

Johnston told the Financial Review that Suncorp had “lost sight” of its core businesses.

Advertisement

“The narrative was too ambitious, and so the narrative became the strategy [but] the strategy was about digitising the business,” he said.

“It’s a digital strategy which goes across … the way we deliver existing products to customers, the creation of new products, and how we reduce [business] costs.”

Suncorp's board dances at its AGM during a traditional greeting. Attila Csaszar

One new focus is selling insurance via state-based marketing campaigns. Premium brands such as Suncorp will focus on Queensland and GIO in southern states, while AAMI targets the mass market.

The previous campaign had pushed the Suncorp brand nationally, but in southern states this “cost a lot more than we had available to spend”, Johnston said.

Still, he said the strategy had worked with the bank. “Our deposits – transactional banking – went up, simply because we were addressing a brand new customer base,” he said.

Johnston would not flag if premiums, for brands such as AAMI, would be cut to compete. But he added price was not the problem with converting customers.

Another step will be replicating, or “re-skinning”, Suncorp’s app with other brands, such as daubing a version in red and AAMI livery. Johnston argued the app had best-in-class features, but it receives 3.1 stars out of five on Apple reviews and many posts this year slam the technology. “Useless and unreliable,” complained one critic.

Advertisement

Still, Johnston said log-ins had reached almost 455,000 monthly in the past quarter. While that was below internal business projections from nine months ago, it was not materially off target, he argued.

So with Suncorp shifting focus from Marketplace, is it reverting towards a Kodak-style demise? “I don’t think there was ever a threat,” Johnston countered. “We're not complacent about the future … the Kodak example is one of complacency.”

Bouquets and brick bats

Johnston maintained product innovation was central to success, achievable via Suncorp using digital technology and data.

An example he cited was flood insurance: Suncorp (except for AAMI) was the only big insurer with automatic flood cover before 2011. That year, deluges in Queensland’s south-east caused more than $1.5 billion in damage, according to Insurance Council of Australia figures.

The reaction afterwards was astonishing. Customers hung hand-painted signs on fences thanking the insurer. Johnston recalled walking through swamped suburbs wearing Suncorp’s green polo T-shirt. “People were coming out of the streets, responding so positively,” he said.

The reaction is not always so welcoming. Suncorp copped a bruising at the financial services royal commission – with one focus on AAMI customers upset about Victorian bushfire payments. Subsequent increased regulatory costs and remediation has seen Suncorp now set aside $155 million.

Internally, the company wants to embed a cost-saving focus, rather than engage on big projects. Cutbacks recently have been hard – Suncorp staff numbers fell 6 per cent since 2015 to 13,040, according to company accounts, and employee-initiated turnover was high at 14.2 per cent.

Advertisement

Johnston said he thought morale was “OK” but stressed the company must clearly communicate any issues to staff.

It will take more than clear communication to rebuild momentum. Credit Suisse analysts last week branded Suncorp an “underperform”, saying the company could review earnings targets in coming months, including ambitions of return on equity hitting 10 per cent. It was 8.4 per cent last year.

“The current targets are unlikely to be achieved in coming years, in our view, unless Suncorp unwinds the work of previous years and takes on more risk again,” the analysts said.

Former Suncorp CEO John Mulcahy says Johnston is a top strategic thinker. Peter Braig

Changes are under way, such as returning control of stores and distribution back to banking and insurance lines. It is a move back to core operations, a theme receiving backing. “It should … lead to a sharper focus, potentially enabling the company to overcome some of its recent growth difficulties, with mortgage growth sluggish and motor and home [policy numbers] falling,” Citigroup analysts wrote after full-year results.

Those results saw Suncorp’s cash-profits rise 1.5 per cent at $1.115 billion.

The profits were the first with Johnston in control and his ascension was generally well received.

John Mulcahy, Suncorp’s chief executive between 2003 and 2009, described Johnston as a good selection. "He's smart ... understands the business," Mulcahy told the Financial Review. "I found him one of the most strategic and clear thinkers."

Advertisement

Another who has worked with Johnston said: “He observes and he recognises and he understands."

Johnston has lived in Brisbane all his life, albeit having travelled frequently. His parents owned and ran a petrol station and he attended Mansfield State High in the city’s south-east.

Former Suncorp chief Patrick Snowball once dubbed Johnston the company's “consigliere”. Louie Douvis

Now his job will potentially pay $5.4 million, including bonuses. That cash will add to property and company searches listing his home as a modest eastern waterfront property bought for $820,000 in 2002, while his family also owns a $1.7 million inner-city home and a $1.2 million apartment on the Gold Coast.

Johnston, 53, who has two adult children, holidays there when the apartment is not rented out. He also enjoys watching rugby league, playing tennis and running, although lately does not “get much time”.

It’s the apex of a diverse career from policy adviser to managing Telstra's government and investor relations. He started at Suncorp in 2006, initially in similar relations positions, and was part of critical moments including Suncorp's GFC tremors when the banking arm was nearly sold. His last position was chief financial officer. His knowledge was such that Patrick Snowball, Suncorp chief executive from 2009 to 2015, once dubbed Johnston its “consigliere”.

Operational experience

But some issues gnaw: one is how Johnston can oversee the financial conglomerate having never been a traditional insurer or banker himself. He countered that in almost 14 years he had been “at the coal face” of Suncorp’s big decisions.

Advertisement

“Yes, I haven’t run a contact centre with 1500-2000 people. But I ran the finance team with 750 and that’s a complex organisation in and of itself that has to deliver a pile of material,” Johnston said.

One critic also questioned how Johnston had stood for years as Cameron’s right-hand man, now only to attack the past strategy.

Johnston admitted he bore responsibility. “I've never shirked any responsibility I had for any performance of the company. I didn’t seek to in front of the board, when I talked to the board about being a candidate … I fronted into that issue,” he said.

Suncorp chairwoman Christine McLoughlin expressed confidence in the Marketplace strategy. Attila Csaszar

It is a similar question for Christine McLoughlin, who on becoming Suncorp chairwoman last year said she was “pleased” with Marketplace's progress.

“The investment that we made in the functionality of the Marketplace is now enabling us to get on with doing what we’re doing in our insurance and banking businesses,” McLoughlin told the Financial Review. “What we didn’t do well was communicate what we were doing.”

Now the company has breathing room to communicate a new strategy. Investors will hope this one lasts. Successfully. Like a Wiggles song.
description: Steve Johnston has seen bruising parliamentary battles and knows Suncorp's skeletons. Is he the right man, with the right strategy, to fix its ailments?
